item.title: 205 – Magic Tricks
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Magic Tricks I bought 24 bottles of water for $3. Tonight, my cat will eat better than most of the rest of the world. I did not die due to the following: Ebola, gunfire, ground-to-air missiles, poorly aimed mortars, indifference. … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Magic Tricks

I bought 24 bottles of water
for $3.

Tonight, my cat will eat
better than most of the rest of the world.

I did not die
due to the following:

Ebola, gunfire, ground-to-air missiles,
poorly aimed mortars, indifference.

I take refuge
from loud neighbors

and awkward social situations.
My toilet works. I have electricity.

The radio keeps me informed
and is easily turned off.

Someone else raised, killed
and shipped the chicken

I ate for dinner.
I am typing now online

without fear of reprisal
or censorship.

I’m a simple man
living a simple life.

What else is there,
anyway?

item.title: 204 – Leaving Waukegan
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Leaving Waukegan God bless you Tom Waits driving I-5 through East LA gruffly telling the Muse to fuck off, come back when you’re not stuck in rush hour traffic. It’s probably apocryphal, the kind of story ginned up at cocktail … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Leaving Waukegan

God bless you Tom Waits
driving I-5 through East LA
gruffly telling the Muse
to fuck off, come back
when you’re not stuck
in rush hour traffic.

It’s probably apocryphal,
the kind of story ginned up
at cocktail parties and campfires
about a man wrestling an angel
down in the dirt, demanding
a name, limping the rest of his life
for the effort.

Probably you just pulled over
in the shoulder, flashing hazards,
scrambling for a pencil nub
and the back of your hand
divinely inspired to scribe
the melody of Jockey Full of Bourbon

like the rest of us, poor saps,
who swallowed the lie
that genius lives inside each one
like some sleek-suited Grendel
who’ll make the best of us
out our own blood.

Maybe that’s why you sound how you do.
Torn up inside, growling
at the little god clawing its way out
as you sing.

item.title: 203 – Advice
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Advice Dear Anne Landers or Abby or anybody with an ear and a WIFI connection: what’s the right Bible verse for cancer? How do you boil an egg so the whites come out just right? Where would we get 40 … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Advice
Dear Anne Landers
or Abby or anybody
with an ear and a WIFI connection:
what’s the right Bible verse
for cancer? How do you boil an egg
so the whites come out just right?
Where would we get 40 acres and a mule
for everyone who deserves it? Who deserves it?
I’m at the end of what little rope I’ve been dealt
making coils around my hand and finding only
the same empty palm at the center.
Who am I kidding? No one reads the paper
or the comments section where the answers
and slurs and unhelpful vitriol spew out
to my (and a million other) simple queries.
Crowd source your life, just be careful
what you wish for: a once singular thing
gone viral in the worst way. Christ I thought
and think and sometimes pray knows
what’s going on. But then a plane comes down
in an empty field or a kid I’m blood to but never met
dies at thirteen. Lives built out of balsa wood
and best intentions splinter, shudder, fall
and there’s no tornado around to take the blame.
Some days I don’t know why I even bother asking
for advice: I know the answer. Dig the tomb yourself
and seal in behind the stone. The trick is to wait
those three days that seem like forever
until the light pours in, when and if
the light pours in. Does the light pour in?
It does, the thinking goes, or so I’ve clung to
though it may not seem like much, that light,
just the same as a dirty pale sheet waving
from the trenches. Surrender, that’s the thing. To kneel
in the dirt, breathe the air you didn’t make
in lungs you couldn’t carve, and, despite
the shit that’s in your teeth and eye, say thanks
and mean it, true. That’s the only advice
there is: throw up your hands and see who comes
when you call, if at all.

item.title: 202 – Things I Think When You’re Late Coming Home
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Things I Think When You’re Late Coming Home none of them good & every sound is you but not you these are nights God made for praying the siren is for fire far off I hope this is the road … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Things I Think When You’re Late Coming Home

none of them good
& every sound is you
but not

you

these are nights
God made
for

praying

the siren
is for fire
far off

I hope

this is the road
I fear
and never want

to walk

item.title: 201 – Gardening
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Gardening the apples sing their falling song all night on our roof. it wakes the cat and us from dreams of fortresses and wine. we press together hooked at the knees and hips. in the morning bending at the waist … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Gardening

the apples sing their falling song
all night on our roof. it wakes the cat
and us from dreams of fortresses
and wine. we press together
hooked at the knees and hips.
in the morning bending at the waist
to pluck and pluck again the sweet rot
of browning fruit found on the ground
we sing the song God gave
in the garden to all creation.

we fill a barrel and flies follow
in the heat of afternoon. here it is
all at once: the full height of life
left to fall and seep and end
and in the very instant feed
the tail of its telling to the mouth
open and waiting. we are the apples
and the falling. we are the song
sung since the root of the garden
was laid, since before there were roots
or gardens.

item.title: 200 – Meeror
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Meeror I slapt his neediness away a dead hand     clammy cold to touch think on it settled on the bed frondled fingers streaming w/ the current had I plunged an arm thru my own waving face stones & trout his … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Meeror

I slapt his neediness away
a dead hand     clammy cold
to touch

think on it

settled on the bed
frondled fingers streaming
w/ the current

had I plunged
an arm thru my own waving face
stones & trout

his grip: just like mine, I’m sure

item.title: 199 – Reading Jack Gilbert in the Woods
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Reading Jack Gilbert in the Woods We buy wood to burn in the wilderness: bringing home the dead. The fire goes all night by a stream that refuses to settle its name. The flames die at last for all has … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Reading Jack Gilbert in the Woods

We buy wood to burn
in the wilderness: bringing home the dead.
The fire goes all night
by a stream that refuses to settle its name.
The flames die at last
for all has been fed to it–everything consumed.
We will carry the burnt husks
that remain out in a light rain, under mist.
We leave the ashes we’ve made
in the woods, blackened stones ringing what’s left.

item.title: 198 – Love Poem
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: July 17, 2014 I am terrible at love poems. No one dies in them. Too much sun and such. The kiss that comes is a groan to me. But I feel a dreadful lovely thing hunching its back inside me–the … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
July 17, 2014

I am terrible at love
poems. No one dies
in them. Too much sun
and such. The kiss
that comes is a groan
to me. But I feel
a dreadful lovely thing
hunching its back
inside me–the heart?
the thing beneath
the heart?–bursting
its thousand mouths
to say the same.
It’s just not my way
to say it straight
when slant and arch
sting so good.
The scar’s the thing. Love,
I do, and said so
once in front of God
and everybody, and a thousand times
since to the wind so you’ll hear
me speak when you least
expect or want.
That’s just how we work
I suppose: stuck together
until death do us part,
though some days even
that seems a little like cheating.

item.title: 197 – If I Die First
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: If I Die First Bury me beneath the marriage oak. Then dig me up and prop me on the couch to keep you company. I’ll scare away the beasties and let you sleep well at night. Even a tin of … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
If I Die First

Bury me beneath the marriage oak.

Then dig me up

and prop me on the couch

to keep you company.

I’ll scare away the beasties

and let you sleep well at night.

Even a tin of ash I make

the tomatoes grow six feet tall

and giant. Taste me in the summer;

can me, the vine-ripened sweetness lingers

long into the fall.

item.title: 196 – Kiss
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Kiss And the Lord came down in his glory to kiss us each full on the mouth and some day’s that’s all I know.
item.content:encoded:
Kiss

And the Lord came down
in his glory to kiss
us each full
on the mouth
and some day’s
that’s all I know.
